item.title: Containers vs. Virtual Machines (VMs)
item.description: Using Docker: The What, The Why, and The Architecture Context: This is part of my DevOps course. I was reading the book “Using Docker: Developing and Deploying Software with Containers” by Adrian Mouat. The “What” and “Why” of Containers Containers are a way to distribute your software with the exact same environment within which it was developed. This makes it hassle-free to set up the environment on every different system where you want to run the software.

item.title: journal 2025-12-06
item.description: Saturday, December 06, 2025 What did I work on today? I worked literally on nothing today What did I learn today? Topic: Containers vs VM’s (Book: Using docker by Adrian Mouat) The Why: Solves “it works on my machine.” Containers bundle app + libs (user space) but share the Host Kernel. Key Architecture Difference: VM’s: Hardware → HostOS → Hypervisor → GuestOS(heavy) → App Containers: Hardware → HostOS → Container Engine → No GuestOS (light) → App Performance: VM calls are expensive (Guest Kernel → Hypervisor → Host Kernel → Hardware), Containers run as native processes on HostOS, making it’s startup fast.
